channel.title: Id
channel.description:
Well...I'm trying to test something, and I need to know how to make the ID of a button appear next to the button text when you hover over it...Say....You hover over the yes emote button:
Ok, 183
Or whatever the ID for it is.....
So, how would I do this? I believe it is client sided...

item.title: Id
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Mmmm, nope…

I just want to find the sendquest ID’s of normal words…Like…Words on a scroll. Words you cannot click, but you can change.

For non clickables, you would have to dump the interfaces. I posted a dump of items, npcs, objects and interfaces in the server downloads section.

item.title: Id
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:16, topic:291958”]Really?

Ok, look for this in the client:

.aString221;

And replace that with this:

.aString221 + " (" + class9_1.anInt250 + ")";

That should work.[/quote]

Well, it shows the…

addClickableText(2001, “Sword-Wielding Lvl:”, “Sword-Wielding Guide”, wid, 0, 0xffffff, 90, 11);

That ID. The ID I set it to, but when I try to change it in say…Texthandler serversided…It does not change.

EDIT: Nevermind. It DID change after a bit. (Was not in process()

Thanks!

P.S…Know how to find the sendquest ID’s of non-clickable text by any chance?

Read full topic

item.title: Id

@zyle1992 wrote:

Really?

Ok, look for this in the client:

.aString221;

And replace that with this:

.aString221 + " (" + class9_1.anInt250 + ")";

That should work.

Ok. Go into client.java of the client, and replace all

class9_1;

With this:

class9_1.aString221 + " (" + class9_1.anInt250 + ")";

item.title: Id
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:10, topic:291958”]Ok, here’s your fix:

Ok, in YOUR Class9.java, look for “Ok”, and you should see this:

if(class9.anInt217 == 1)
                        class9.aString221 = "Ok ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 4)
                        class9.aString221 = "Select ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 5)
                        class9.aString221 = "Select ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 6)
                        class9.aString221 = "Continue ";

Replace that with this:

if(class9.anInt217 == 1) class9.aString221 = "Ok " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 4) class9.aString221 = "Select " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 5) class9.aString221 = "Select " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 6) class9.aString221 = "Continue " + class9.anInt250;

And you should be good to go.[/quote]

That’s showing the…Interface ID. For my interfaces…

Read full topic

item.title: Id
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ok, here’s your fix:

Ok, in YOUR Class9.java, look for “Ok”, and you should see this:

if(class9.anInt217 == 1)
                        class9.aString221 = "Ok ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 4)
                        class9.aString221 = "Select ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 5)
                        class9.aString221 = "Select ";
                    if(class9.anInt217 == 6)
                        class9.aString221 = "Continue ";

Replace that with this:

if(class9.anInt217 == 1) class9.aString221 = "Ok " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 4) class9.aString221 = "Select " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 5) class9.aString221 = "Select " + class9.anInt250; if(class9.anInt217 == 6) class9.aString221 = "Continue " + class9.anInt250;

And you should be good to go.

Read full topic

Or if there’s any other good way of figuring out sendquest ID’s…
